Georgia continues to make progress in the fight against human trafficking. We are grateful for federal, state, and local law enforcement and their commitment to the safety of our families. Together, we will end this evil industry once and for all. #gapol

There is evil around us. Thankfully, we have men & women in uniform who will risk it all to keep us safe. Today, they are rescuing children from trafficking. Tomorrow, they are putting violent criminals behind bars. These Georgians have earned our respect & deserve our support.

As part of “Operation Not Forgotten”, federal and state law enforcement rescued 39 innocent children and put numerous criminals behind bars. This is another step forward in the fight to end sex trafficking and save lives in Georgia. #gapol

According to law enforcement officials, the seizure of 375 pounds of heroin last month in Atlanta is the largest bust in Georgia history. More importantly, agents believe this joint operation will cripple drug trafficking in the Southeast for years. #gapol

With the signing of Senate Bill 288, we are taking another measured step forward on criminal justice reform in Georgia. The "Second Chance Bill" will reduce recidivism rates, boost workforce participation, and ultimately keep Georgia families safe. #gapol

Peaceful protests were hijacked by criminals with a dangerous, destructive agenda. Now, innocent Georgians are being targeted, shot, and left for dead. This lawlessness must be stopped and order restored in our capital city.
In Georgia, we stand against violence and with law enforcement. Rest assured, these criminals will be held accountable for their destructive and dangerous behavior. #gapol

For years, cartels have used GA as a distribution hub for drugs, weapons, & lives. By working in coordination w/ fed, state, & local law enforcement, we are dismantling their supply chain & protecting communities from dangerous, violent criminals. #gapol

This kind of leadership from law enforcement, working with community leaders, will get us through. But we cannot, and will not stand for violence, looting, and criminal activity. 8/8

Today, we are announcing recommendations from the State’s Law Enforcement Reform Partnership to strengthen policing policies, improve information sharing around disciplinary actions and increase officer training.
These steps call for updates to Use of Force and Duty to Intervene policies, improved information sharing across all law enforcement agencies, and an increase in officer training requirements.
Further, Tennessee law expressly prohibits camping on state property not expressly designated as a campground area, and that law will be enforced.
We encourage Tennesseans to exercise their First Amendment rights and have seen many examples of peaceful protests across our state in recent weeks.

Just last night, I watched citizens engage peacefully on the steps of our State Capitol. I commend these protestors for their candor and respectful engagement, and I commend our law enforcement, first responders, and the National Guard for their faithful service during this time.

Some have hijacked peaceful protests for their own ends, and to those I say: we will not tolerate violence against people or property in Tennessee. 

Violence does not represent our state – it tears at the fabric of who we are and it hurts our ability to learn from one another.
My heart is with those who are hurting, and with those who are bravely and peacefully speaking out against injustices that continue to exist in our country.

So far this year, it seems that every week brings a new and remarkable challenge. Certainly, this past week has continued down that path. The profound protests of recent days have gripped our attention, as they should.
The protests in Murfreesboro are no longer peaceful demonstrations but have escalated to overt threats to public safety and property.
Violence and vandalism that occurred this weekend tears at the fabric of our community and stands in stark contrast to effective, peaceful protests that are foundational to our country.

We believe many who engaged in unlawful acts of violence last night are not from Tennessee and I have directed the Department of Safety and Homeland Security to investigate further in coordination with local law enforcement and the TBI.

The threat to both peace and property is unacceptable and we will work with local law enforcement and community leaders to restore safety and order. This is not a reflection of our state or the fundamental American right to peaceful protest.
At the request of Mayor Cooper, I am authorizing the National Guard to mobilize in response to protests that have now taken a violent, unlawful turn in Nashville.

The law enforcement reforms I moved forward with yesterday represent the most transformative changes New Hampshire has ever made to our law enforcement system. Read about my Executive Order here:

Today I put forward a roadmap to implement 48 recommendations from the LEACT Commission I established after the murder of George Floyd. From body-cams for State Police to updating training methods, these are the most comprehensive law enforcement reforms this state has ever seen.

We've identified four avenues for implementation:
1) Reforms we can make immediately through Executive Order
2) Reforms we can immediately initiate through rulemaking
3) Reforms that needed to be taken up by the legislature
4) Reforms implemented by local law enforcement agencies

THREAD: Today I released a plan for NH to implement all recommendations from the Commission on Law Enforcement Accountability, Community, & Transparency, focusing on: training, reporting & investigation of police misconduct, and community relations. THREAD: While the current guidance in place for NH restaurants is not changing today, we will be kicking up our enforcement of restaurants and bars that fail to follow the state’s public guidelines.

I have also granted the Commission a 30-day extension to develop recommendations on:

1. Reporting and investigations of police misconduct
2. How to improve relations between law enforcement and the communities they serve.

(/3)

These action items found consensus between all members of this commission - from community activists to our law enforcement representatives. We need to move quickly to implement these recommendations. It's time to get it done. (/2)

THREAD: Late last week, I received the initial report from the NH Commission on Law Enforcement Accountability, Community, and Transparency with recommendations on law enforcement training. My office has reviewed these initial training recommendations, and we endorse them all.

Prohibits the use of chokeholds by law enforcement
Prohibits private prisons in NH
Requires police officers to report misconduct
Additional bail reform
